meeting_annotations.speaker: PB
meeting_annotations.transcript: Ellen, I would, I would add to what Venkat is saying is that if I look at traditional large-scale processes, industry folks would generally use a time scale of your turnover. It's much easier to say what's infeasible than to say what is feasible. And if the time scale of your turnover is on the order of hours typically, that's not going to translate or scale well to an industrial process. So that's sort of a ballpark, not strict number, but, but a good rule of thumb in industrial processes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: CM
meeting_annotations.transcript: One thing just to add to here is if you think about a biological system, basically you have a bunch of machinery, a protein, you have a bunch of machinery that's basically just dictating the local chemical microenvironment of the catalytic active center. Maybe I'm biased because this is what I work on, but you can take a molecular catalyst that you know does this like a, a, an N4 catalyst and put it in polymers that mimic a lot of this, which is cheaper. It mimics all of the delivery and you can get, and then you still have low site density, but you can build up layers of this on the surface. You can build vertically and you can get these three, basically 3D architectures of these polymer catalyst composites.
